repnme.cdata!:
Ghana - Urban Environmental Sanitation
            Project, Village Infrastructure Project, and Second
            Community Water and Sanitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings were as follows: The Ghana Urban
            Environmental Sanitation Project had a satisfactory outcome,
            unlikely sustainability, and modest institutional
            development impact; the Village Infrastructure Project had a
            satisfactory outcome, likely sustainability, and high
            institutional development impact; and the Second Community
            Water and Sanitation Project had a highly satisfactory
            outcome, likely sustainability, and substantial
            institutional development impact. The Bank's and
            Borrower's performances were satisfactory for all three
            projects. Three lessons were cited: 1) Decentralization
            requires an enabling institutional environment including: a
            long term commitment, a demand-driven approach including
            beneficiary contributions, clear institutional roles and
            guidance for all stakeholders, and a common implementation
            modality for all actors. 2) A major drive to build
            implementation capacity is essential including: major
            training for local governments, communities and private
            sector support services, emphasis on up-front capacity
            building before investment in infrastructure, strong central
            coordination including monitoring and evaluation, and
            integration of hygiene education alongside the investment
            program; and 3)  Sustainability needs to be a central focus
            including: priority on raising revenues for operations and
            maintenance, institutional adjustments to improve revenue
            collection, self-sustaining support services from the
            private sector, and follow-on training for the local
            governments and community organizations.

repnme.cdata!:
A demand driven approach in service
            delivery : the community water and sanitation program in Ghana

abstracts.cdata!:
In 2000, the Second Community Water and
            Sanitation Project (CWSP2) was initiated with support of a
            World Bank IDA credit of US$21.9 million. The project built
            on lessons learned from the first Community Water and
            Sanitation Project (CWSP1,) and adopted a large-scale
            decentralization approach in the planning, implementation
            and management of water supply and sanitation (WSS) services
            in Ghana. The development objective of the CWSP2 was to
            increase access and achieve effective and sustained use of
            improved community WSS services in villages and small towns
            in four regions in Ghana. An important feature of the
            project was the decentralized approach to rural WSS services
            delivery which placed Districts in the driving seat of implementation.

repnme.cdata!:
Ghana - Second Community Water and
            Sanitation Project in Support of the First Phase of the
            Community Water and Sanitation Program

abstracts.cdata!:
The Project for Ghana had the following
            ratings: the outcome was highly satisfactory, the
            sustainability was likely, the institutional development
            impact was substantial, and the Bank and borrower
            performance were both satisfactory. Lessons learned: The
            project's ability to exceed the access target in the
            Development Objective by an additional 40 percent coupled
            with the strengthening of local institutions and systems to
            ensure sustained delivery capacity demonstrates the
            potential of decentralized water and sanitation services.
            Strong district ownership and leadership is key. Funds flow
            from center to local level should be efficient. Capacity
            building strengthens implementation and operation and
            maintenance. District planning underpins strategic
            decision-making. Private sector capacity to respond to
            demand is crucial. Adequate supply chains promote efficient
            and sustainable delivery. Significant benefits could only be
            derived if at least half of community members owned latrines
            and made this an access criteria for subsidies. Ghana
            ownership was consistent at all levels, most notably the
            Ministry of Finance, the Ministry of Local Government. Over
            2,000 communities assisted by the project are adequately
            using and maintaining their water facilities.

repnme.cdata!:
Ghana - Second Community Water and
            Sanitation Project (CWSP2) : fifth quality of supervision
            assessment (QSA5) - summary assessment sheet

abstracts.cdata!:
The panel rated the supervision of this
            Second Community Water and Sanitation Project for Ghana as
            highly satisfactory with the two subcategories - focus on
            development effectiveness and adequacy of supervision inputs
            and processes - also rated highly satisfactory. The project
            became effective on 7/19/2000, almost eleven month after
            Board presentation. This was the major initial problem. The
            two effectiveness conditions, which took a long time to be
            resolved, were: (i) the nomination of the Central Water
            Sanitation Agency (CWSA) Board, and (ii) Parliamentary
            approval of the subsidiary grant agreement between the
            Government and CWSA. There was a close follow up of the
            effectiveness issue by the Bank through the resident mission
            and the 2000 CPPR was instrumental in raising to the
            attention of Government of Ghana (GOG) senior managers the
            urgency of obtaining Parliamentary approval for all pending
            subsidiary grants agreement under Bank credits. With regard
            to the issue of harmonization of the water supply/sanitation
            policies, the Bank team has been very proactive in reaching
            out to other donors with a view to convince them to adopt a
            common sector wide approach, and progress is being made.
            Conditions for effectiveness have to be strictly minimized
            and reduced to the legal opinion and the signing of
            subsidiary agreements, if and when applicable. In this case,
            delay could have been reduced if the nomination of the Board
            could have been made a condition of Board presentation.

Ghana - Second Community Water and
            Sanitation Project (CWSP2)

abstracts.cdata!:
The Adaptable Program Loan (APL)
            supports the Government of Ghana in extending sustainable
            water and sanitation facilities to 85 percent of the rural
            population by the year 2009 and in establishing a
            sustainable operations and maintenance system in rural
            communities and small towns. The Second Community Water and
            Sanitation Project (CWSP2) will be implemented in three
            3-year phases. The first phase for CWSP2 aims to increase
            service coverage, and achieve effective and sustained use of
            improved community water and sanitation in villages and
            small towns in four regions. There are two main project
            components. The Community Subprojects component provides
            grants to communities and schools through their district
            assemblies for construction of water and sanitation
            facilities and finances technical assistance and community
            development activities to strengthen community capacity to
            plan, implement, operate, and maintain water and sanitation
            facilities in an effective and sustainable manner. Community
            subprojects include protected communal hand-dug wells,
            communal boreholes equipped with handpumps, a mechanized
            boreholes, a surface water supply system, a protected spring
            source, rainwater catchment, and household and school
            latrines. The second component strengthens stakeholder
            capacity by supporting the private sector and
            nongovernmental organizations as providers of hardware and
            software services, and provides national program development.
